author: -I'm the guy that posts your game porn-

text: This is waaaaaay better than the SNES version. Compared them to see what the fuss was about. The SNES versions treble is barely audible, so all you can hear is the (over-powering) drums and the melody is almost muted. Can see that the quality of the Genesis instruments isn't great, but overall this version, whilst harsher, is certainly more clear and not completely overpowered by drums + bass.

text: @Bigbudd0045 The genesis soundchip is objectively superior, but suffers from incompetent development most of the time. Any song from a game like Granada or Sol-Deace would sound like dick on the SNES.
author: Snufl

text: +Ghreivyn it is not objectively superior, its garbage.  compare any game that was on both platforms, the music on the snes version is better.
author: Bigbudd0045

text:
@Bigbudd0045
The majority of games used the default soundset, because it would cost them money to make a proper one. With a proper soundset, the genesis sounds better in every way.
author: Snufl

text: +Ghreivyn yeah, no.  The Genesis has a distinct metalic sound to it.  It works best in games that take advantage of it.  But every game that came out with the same music on it for SNES and Gen, sounds better on the SNES.  The reverberation on the SNES is due to the way the chip worked. The SNES is a much better piece of hardware, benefiting from coming out later than the GEN.  The SMS is superior on technical level to the NES, but the same doesnt hold true for the next gen.
author: Bigbudd0045

text: +Bigbudd0045 This song in particular is better in the Genesis version, with a much richer sound.

author: Myriachan

text:
Basically, the hardware wasn't up to snuff in game consoles way back when. So people had to make up for the lack of good technology with good melodies.

Games now and days still have good music, but it's much easier to figure out who really isn't a good musician now compared to back then. A lot of them, haha...
author: 0 MP Matt

text: I don't know why, I don't rank it up there as one of the most epic tracks, but this is one I could literally loop for hours and not notice the time disappear.
author: Xavior86

text:
Thunder Force 3 sounded MUCH better than Thunder Spirits. That's probably the best example of where the Genesis/MD excelled. 

Basically, the Mega Drive's modular synthesis was better for electronic, high tempo compositions, and the SNES's sample based music was better for "out the box" "orchestral" sounding music. A better music programmer could generally get more out of the Genesis, but a mid range one could do better with the set samples of the SNES.

author: Prinsdam

text: @SyriusBelsferg It wasn't just the Genesis, pretty much 50% of all games on every platform back then never made adequate use of their respective sound hardware. There were plenty of great soundtracks on the Genesis- the Sonic games, Streets of Rage 1 and 2 and all of Treasure and Konami's games are the obvious examples, but then there were the hidden gems like ResQ, Dangerous Seed, Socket, Verytex, Jewel Master, Shura no Mon, ATP Tour Championship Tennis, M.U.S.H.A., The Hybrid Front...
